summary: This is a 2021 opinion and order by Judge Alison J. Nathan in the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case, resolving multiple pretrial motions. The court denies Maxwell's motions to dismiss based on Epstein's 2007 non-prosecution agreement and statute of limitations, but grants her motion to sever the perjury charges for a separate trial. The opinion analyzes the scope and applicability of Epstein's NPA in detail. This document is a court opinion and order (Document 207) from the criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell, filed on April 16, 2021. It addresses several of Maxwell's pre-trial motions, including challenges to the statute of limitations, pre-indictment delay, specificity of the indictment, and the legal tenability of perjury charges. The court denies her motions, finding the charges are governed by an extended statute of limitations, the delay did not violate due process, the indictment is sufficiently specific, and the perjury charges present questions for the jury. This is a court opinion and order (Document 207) from Judge Alison J. Nathan in the criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell (1:20-cr-00330). The court denies most of Maxwell's pretrial motions but grants her motion to sever the perjury counts for a separate trial. It also addresses motions to dismiss, strike surplusage, and compel discovery, setting deadlines for the parties to negotiate a pretrial disclosure schedule.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Charged with facilitating Jeffrey Epstein's sexual abuse of minors and perjury. Filed multiple pretrial motions seeking dismissal, suppression of evidence, and severance of charges.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Late financier, subject of non-prosecution agreement
persons.context: Deceased financier whose 2007 non-prosecution agreement with the Southern District of Florida is central to Maxwell's motion to dismiss. The agreement included a provision not to prosecute potential co-conspirators.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Author of the opinion and order, presiding over the Maxwell criminal case in the Southern District of New York.

connections.description: Maxwell is charged as a co-conspirator of Epstein in facilitating the sexual abuse of minors. The court analyzes whether Epstein's NPA, which covered 'potential co-conspirators,' applies to her.
Judge Nathan is presiding over Maxwell's criminal case and issuing rulings on her motions.

events.title: Epstein enters Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein entered into a non-prosecution agreement (NPA) with the U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida. He agreed to plead guilty in Florida state court to soliciting minors for prostitution in exchange for the federal office agreeing not to charge him or his 'potential co-conspirators' with federal crimes in that district stemming from the 2001-2007 investigation.

events.title: Grand jury returns indictment against Maxwell
events.description: A grand jury returned a six-count indictment charging Ghislaine Maxwell with facilitating Epstein's sexual abuse of minor victims from around 1994 to 1997.

events.title: Scheduled trial date for Maxwell
events.description: Trial was set to begin on July 12, 2021, for the charges in the S1 superseding indictment.

events.title: Alleged criminal conduct period
events.description: The S1 superseding indictment charges Maxwell with conduct occurring exclusively between 1994 and 1997, involving the enticement and transportation of minors for illegal sex acts.

events.title: Maxwell's civil depositions
events.description: The perjury counts against Maxwell stem from depositions she gave in 2016, more than eight years after Epstein signed the NPA.

events.title: Enactment of the PROTECT Act
events.description: Congress amended 18 U.S.C. ยง 3283 to eliminate the statute of limitations for prosecuting offenses involving the sexual abuse of a minor during the victim's lifetime.

events.title: Florida Investigation of Epstein
events.description: A police detective in Palm Beach investigated Jeffrey Epstein. Maxwell suggests this detective's testimony would have been exculpatory, but the court finds it would have been propensity evidence.

events.title: Maxwell's Civil Deposition
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell gave a deposition in a civil defamation case. Her answers in this deposition form the basis for the perjury charges in the criminal indictment.

events.title: Court Issues Pretrial Ruling
events.description: Judge Alison J. Nathan issues an opinion and order denying most of Ghislaine Maxwell's pretrial motions but granting her motion to sever the perjury counts for a separate trial.

events.title: Government Produces Discovery
events.description: The Government produces over 20,000 pages of interview notes, reports, and other materials related to non-testifying witnesses.

events.title: Deadline for Proposals and Show Cause
events.description: Court orders Maxwell to show cause why her grand jury motion should not be dismissed as moot, and orders parties to submit a joint proposal for a pretrial disclosure schedule.

keyFacts: Judge Nathan ruled that Jeffrey Epstein's 2007 non-prosecution agreement does not bar the prosecution of Ghislaine Maxwell in the Southern District of New York, as it only bound the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida.

The court found that the NPA did not cover the offenses charged against Maxwell, as the Mann Act counts alleged conduct from 1994-1997, predating the 2001-2007 scope of the Florida investigation, and the perjury counts stemmed from 2016 depositions.
The court granted Maxwell's motion to sever the perjury counts from the Mann Act counts, ordering they be tried separately.
The court denied Maxwell's motion to dismiss based on the statute of limitations, applying the PROTECT Act's life-of-the-victim limit for offenses involving the sexual abuse of minors.

The opinion references a Department of Justice Office of Professional Responsibility report that found Epstein's NPA was 'unusual in many respects, including its breadth, leniency, and secrecy' and reflected 'poor judgment.'

The court ruled that the extended statute of limitations under 18 U.S.C. ยง 3283, as amended by the 2003 PROTECT Act, applies to the charges against Ghislaine Maxwell, allowing prosecution for alleged conduct that occurred more than 20 years prior.

The court rejected Maxwell's due process claim based on pre-indictment delay, finding she failed to show the government intentionally delayed for an improper purpose or that the delay (including deaths of witnesses like Epstein) seriously prejudiced her defense.

The court found the S1 superseding indictment was sufficiently specific, rejecting Maxwell's arguments that it was vague for using approximate time periods, describing 'grooming,' and not naming the alleged victims.
The court declined to dismiss the perjury charges, finding the questions in Maxwell's civil deposition were not 'fundamentally ambiguous' and that materiality and falsity were questions for the jury.

The document reveals Maxwell's defense strategy included arguing that pretrial publicity and deceased witnesses (Epstein, his mother, a detective, an associate of a victim) prejudiced her case, which the court found speculative.
The court granted Ghislaine Maxwell's motion to sever the perjury counts from the Mann Act counts, ordering separate trials to avoid prejudice and potential disqualification of her counsel.
The court denied Maxwell's motion to dismiss the indictment based on Jeffrey Epstein's non-prosecution agreement, statute of limitations, pre-indictment delay, and lack of specificity.
The court found the perjury charges legally tenable, ruling that factual disputes about materiality should be resolved by a jury.
The court denied as premature Maxwell's motions to strike surplusage related to 'Minor Victim-3' and to dismiss multiplicitous conspiracy charges.

The court ordered the parties to negotiate a schedule for all remaining pretrial disclosures, including Brady/Giglio material, Jencks Act material, and witness lists, suggesting a timeline of 6-8 weeks before trial.
